articles.headline: Candidates Offer Different Views on Energy Policy
articles.snippet: The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates offer profoundly different approaches to energy policy.
articles.abstract: The Democratic and Republican presidential candidates offer profoundly different approaches to energy policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — As oil prices flirt with record highs, hovering around $95 a barrel on Tuesday, the Democratic and Republican presidential candidates are offering few quick fixes but profoundly different long-term approaches to energy policy.

articles.headline: A Slowdown in Jobs Lost, and Created
articles.snippet: Job cuts in the private sector have fallen to a near-15-year low, but the number of new jobs created by start-up and growing businesses has also been falling.
articles.abstract: Job cuts in the private sector have fallen to a near-15-year low, but the number of new jobs created by start-up and growing businesses has also been falling.
articles.lead_paragraph: For a few years starting in the late 1990s, Honeywell was one of those companies that couldn’t stop announcing job cuts. It cut jobs in 1999, even as the rest of the economy was booming. It cut more jobs in 2000, when the stock market bubble began to leak. After the 9/11 attacks, the company, which makes cockpit controls and other high-technology equipment, announced its biggest layoff of all: 15,800 jobs.

articles.headline: For Abu Dhabi and Citi, Credit Crisis Drove Deal
articles.snippet: A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by Dubai spurred Abu Dhabi to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.
articles.abstract: A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by Dubai spurred Abu Dhabi to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.
articles.lead_paragraph: A falling dollar, a growing pile of oil revenue and an interest in not being overshadowed by neighboring Dubai’s increasingly high profile spurred Abu Dhabi to break with its low-key investing tradition to purchase a big $7.5 billion stake in Citigroup.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Foreclosure Charges by Lender Investigated
articles.snippet: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, has been subpoenaed to determine whether it abused the federal bankruptcy system.
articles.abstract: Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, has been subpoenaed to determine whether it abused the federal bankruptcy system.
articles.lead_paragraph: The federal agency monitoring the bankruptcy courts has subpoenaed Countrywide Financial, the nation’s largest mortgage lender and loan servicer, to determine whether the company’s conduct in two foreclosures in southern Florida represented abuses of the bankruptcy system.

articles.headline: Verizon Plans Wider Options for Cellphone Users
articles.snippet: Verizon Wireless plans to give customers more choice in what phones they can use on its network.
articles.abstract: Verizon Wireless plans to give customers more choice in what phones they can use on its network.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a major shift for the mobile phone industry, Verizon Wireless said yesterday that it planned to give customers far more choice in what phones they could use on its network and how they use them.

articles.headline: In French Suburbs, Same Rage, but New Tactics
articles.snippet: A chilling new factor makes the recent violence in France more menacing: the rioters have taken up hunting shotguns and turned them on the police.
articles.abstract: A chilling new factor makes the recent violence in France more menacing: the rioters have taken up hunting shotguns and turned them on the police.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS, Nov. 27 — Two years after France’s immigrant suburbs exploded in rage, the rituals and acts of resentment have reappeared with an eerie sameness: roving gangs clashing with riot police forces, the government appealing for calm, residents complaining that they are ignored.

articles.headline: Oil Producers See the World and Buy It Up
articles.snippet: Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries have begun a global shopping spree that could increase rapidly.
articles.abstract: Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries have begun a global shopping spree that could increase rapidly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — Flush with petrodollars, oil-producing countries have embarked on a global shopping spree.

articles.headline: To Muslim Girls, Scouts Offer a Chance to Fit In
articles.snippet: Some Muslim communities are forming Girl Scout troops to help girls escape the perception that they are different.
articles.abstract: Some Muslim communities are forming Girl Scout troops to help girls escape the perception that they are different.
articles.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — Sometimes when Asma Haidara, a 12-year-old Somali immigrant, wants to shop at Target or ride the Minneapolis light-rail system, she puts her Girl Scout sash over her everyday clothes, which usually include a long skirt worn over pants as well as a swirling head scarf.

articles.headline: Cable Industry Wins Compromise on F.C.C. Plans
articles.snippet: The F.C.C. chief’s decision to scale back a plan to more tightly regulate cable television was a significant, though not total, victory for the industry.
articles.abstract: The F.C.C. chief’s decision to scale back a plan to more tightly regulate cable television was a significant, though not total, victory for the industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 — In the face of a lobbying blitzkrieg by the cable television industry, the Federal Communications Commission drastically scaled back Tuesday evening a proposal by the agency’s chairman to more tightly regulate the industry.

articles.headline: Senate Race That Fizzled Honed Skills for ’08
articles.snippet: The 12 months in which Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton faced each other in a Senate race are as instructive now as they were riveting then.
articles.abstract: The 12 months in which Rudolph W. Giuliani and Hillary Rodham Clinton faced each other in a Senate race are as instructive now as they were riveting then.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York stepped before a wall of television crews in the Public Hearing Room at City Hall on May 19, 2000, there were no surprises left.
